title: Public Property

articles.content:
When you clamor for public ownership of the means of production, you are
clamoring for public ownership of the mind.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 166

articles.content:
Since “public property” is a collectivist fiction, since the public as a whole
can neither use nor dispose of its “property,” that “property” will always be
taken over by some political “elite,” by a small clique which will then rule
the public—a public of literal, dispossessed proletarians.
articles.attribution:
“The Property Status of the Airwaves,”
Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, 128

acknowledgement:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 166
